Guy asks question about why imperial. Yet another imperial criticizer answers with because it's popular in other places, and it's "easier". Your "rant" about metric was hilariously ignorant as usual.

In case you hadn't noticed the whole computing revolution, absolutely none of the math necessary for constructing and launching rockets is done by hand for quite a while now. If metric is so much "easier", and "makes more sense", why don't any of the computers that are used to launch and build rockets use metric? Computers use base8, not base 10.

People like you who think systems of measurements are a popularity contest are really annoying. The system of measurement that is appropriate for a task depends on the intended user. For human scale things, imperial is much more intuitive and appropriate.
The announcer confused the speed of the first stage and the second stage when describing the landing burn -- the first stage NEVER reached 18000kph.

It's actually not true that the imperial system makes no sense. If you are using fractions, 12 is much more flexible than 10. So is 60. And a foot is about the size of a foot. So...  It is outdated but it doesn't make no sense.

Hi Tim, I like your video's very much.
I think I know why the second camera on the second stage have these weird colours. To me it looks like this camera has its Infra red filter removed, I have done this with one of my own camera's and it gives the same purple hue. The benefit of removing an IR filter is that you can see much more thermal (deeper infrared) information which might help the engineers on the ground. Notice how the bell is more evenly lit with this camera than the other. I might be wrong of course, I'm not a rocket scientist ;).

With regards to metric and the UK - We are in a transition time here with both metric and imperial measures used. Our milk is sold in pints and litres, out fuel is sold in litres but our speedometers and roads signs are miles per hour. We also use centigrade for temperature, but revert to fahrenheit in the news if it gets near 100 degrees? I still think of flying in a plane as height in feet and am still more comfortable with stone as my weight ( 14 pounds is 1 stone) -so I'm 13 and half stone - but its changing all the time with the younger generations.
Is there a date for the next Falcon heavy yet? - I want to come to Florida to see it but need as much notice as possible to buy flights.

The Falcon 9 Wikipedia page needs to be updated. It says that "The first stage can be recovered and reused for GTO payloads up to 5,500 kg" (and that refers to block 5). How did they manage to deliver just over 7 t to GTO without expending the booster?

I have a couple of space economics questions.

How much of the cost of current satellites is driven by the need to reduce mass? Say a current satellite costs $400M and has 5 tonnes mass. If I said 'Make an equally capable satellite, but it can mass up to 10 tonnes', how much would this reduce the cost? If it reduces the cost by $100M, then it makes sense to make the more massive satellite, pay an extra $50M for a Falcon Heavy launch (over F9) and come out $50M better off. If there are considerable cost reductions by not scrimping on mass, this could drive demand for FH launches.

It is possibly a bit early to be asking this, but: How do the costs of New Glenn compare to SpaceX F9 and FH? My initial thoughts are that SpaceX has more flexibility by having two sizes of rocket (NG is similar to FH in lift capacity) and SpaceX's second stage looks much smaller than NG's, therefore one might expect it to be cheaper. As the second stage (and in case of NG, optional third stage) are not recovered on either rocket, cheaper is better. However I am not a rocket scientist, so I don't trust my intuitions here.

One should also explain why the metric is more logical:
A meter was aimed to be 1/40,000,000 of the earth circumstance. Thats why the earth circumstance is nearly 40,000km
With the prefixes you have always 10, 100 or 1000 conversions.
If you have a volume of 10cm x10cm x10cm you have exactly 1 Liter (or 1dm^3)
If you heat 1 Liter water up by one Kelvin you have exactly 1 Joule Energy put into this water etc.

The reasons to define a universal unit system was urgent in Europe where every country, sometimes even different parts of the same country used different ones.
I really hope that the USA will convert fully to metric. Than nobody in the world has to cope with unit conversions (ignoring Liberia and Myanmar, but the don't have such a influence in Media, Engineering and Science like the US)

It's funny. I searched for tomorrow space news on YouTube, nothing. Searched on Google, still nothing. I was getting confused until I searched "tomorrow space news youtube" in full for a channel called TMRO to show up. They really need to work on their SEO.

Tim- the Imperial system is the standard system in aviation, like it or not. It may be a bit old fashioned but it is the world standard. Virtually all aircraft instruments are calibrated in feet and knots - even those built in Europe such as Airbuses. It's just a fact of life. The conversion of the whole industry to metric would be massively expensive and would cause much confusion across the globe.

During WW2 German aircraft used metric but, they lost, and the main victors, the US and the UK, got to set the world standards as aviation got going again after the war.
